nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) as advanced by Peters and collaborators is pseudoscience and should be treated with skepticism
EE prescribes growth rate optimization: maximize long-run geometric average growth rate of wealth
Method: two-asset continuous-time portfolio model with risky asset following geometric Brownian motion dS/S = mu dt + sigma dB and continuous rebalancing, initial wealth normalized to one
Result (EE prescription in the model): the growth-rate-optimal constant portfolio is theta = (mu - r) / sigma squared
Result (mainstream EUT prescription in the model): expected utility maximization with CRRA utility yields optimal theta = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma squared)
Claim: EE and expected utility theory (EUT) make identical portfolio predictions in this model only when relative risk aversion gamma equals one (log utility)
Claim: For a theory to be scientific it must provide testable implications (falsifiability per Popper); EE has so far produced few testable implications
Evidence: Limited progress and application - twelve years since Peters 2011 with few substantive generalizations and many writings rehashing older results
Evidence: EE has not provided worked-out testable prescriptions for more realistic problems (e.g., multi-period consumption-investment problems with stochastic income and consumption choices)

Claim: EE meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience listed on Wikipedia (vague/untestable claims, improper evidence, lack of openness to expert testing, absence of progress, personalization, misleading language)
Evidence (indicator i): Peters and Gell-Mann make grandiose and vague claims such as resolving the fundamental problem of decision theory without concrete, testable applications
Evidence (indicator ii): Improper collection or citation of evidence examples include citing experimental work that has been criticized and citing sources out of context
Evidence (indicator iii): Lack of openness to testing by economics experts â€” most EE papers are not published in mainstream economics journals and many remain unpublished working papers
Evidence (indicators iv-v-vi): EE displays absence of progress (reliance on old results), personalization of criticism, and use of potentially misleading language in abstracts and claims
Assumption: The Popperian falsifiability criterion and indicators of pseudoscience are appropriate demarcation tools for assessing whether an approach is scientific
Conclusion: Until EE provides clear, testable implications and engages with domain experts and appropriate evidence, it should be regarded skeptically and not considered established science
